intro: Draba subamplexicaulis, commonly known as the broad-leafed whitlow grass, is a small flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its basal rosette of broad, fleshy leaves and produces clusters of small, white or pale yellow flowers in early spring. The plant is adapted to harsh alpine environments, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun exposure. It is often found in rocky or gravelly habitats at high elevations. Draba subamplexicaulis is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other flowering plants with similar floral structures.
